About Vancomycin: 
 
Vancomycin is known as the last-resort antibiotic; it is to be used when all other medications have failed, in serious, life-threatening bacterial infections, including meningitis. Despite being useful in fighting such deadly infections, Vancomycin has several side-effects: local pain, allergic reactions, thrombophlebitis (formation of blood clots), nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity. It is difficult to measure the exact safe dose of Vancomycin, because it shows a large variability of pharmacokinetics from patient to patient: it is absorbed differently from person to person, even at the same dose. Therefore, the therapeutic range (i.e. doses at which the drug is effective, without posing toxicity issues) is unique to each individual. Vancomycin administration therefore requires continuous monitoring of the blood concentration, to ensure the medication is useful, while minimising the possibility of side effects. 
 
 Another major problem is the ability of bacteria to mutate and develop resistance against antibiotics. Incorrect dosage of Vancomycin could lead to high drug concentration in the blood, which in time would lead to bacterial resistance to the drug. As this is a last-resort antibiotic, Vancomycin-resistance in bacteria is a serious concern. 
 
 A biosensor designed for Vancomycin detection could be a solution for both these issues, as it would allow for personalised treatment for each individual, based on drug concentrations found in their blood. This biosensor will be designed so it could be used in healthcare institutions and at home as well, while requiring a minimal amount of blood for the measurements.

We are SensImperial, a team of 10 Science and Engineering Students from Imperial College London, and we have designed and prototyped a vancomycin biosensor for the International SensUs Competition. 
 
 Our abilities are covering a wide range, as our team incorporates chemists, medicinal chemists, biomedical engineers and electrical engineers. This was to ensure that our project benefits both on the biochemical part (how do we want to sense the drug?) and on the engineering part (how do we want the sensor to look/be used?). 
 
 We aimed to design a good biosensor, that is reliable, efficient, quick and easy to use. Therefore, we are replacing the classic, box-like biosensors, with our novel approach: an app, downloadable on every smartphone in the world, paired with a nitrocellulose membrane fitted with chemicals which can quantitatively bind and detect vancomycin in blood plasma samples. We are hoping that our final product will be useful to patients and individuals specialised in medicine (medics, nurses etc), allowing for a better, more controlled administration of vancomycin.
